steps.title: Eat 5-6 small meals a day.
steps.content: Eat 5-6 small meals a day. Prednisone can cause an increase in appetite. You might be tempted to snack more than you are used to while taking prednisone. To counteract that temptation, try reducing the size of your meals and eating more often. [1] X Trustworthy Source University of California San Francisco Health Center Research hospital associated with UCSF, a leading medical university, providing innovative patient care and public health resources Go to source Eating smaller meals can also help you digest.

steps.title: Find sources of lean protein.
steps.content: Find sources of lean protein. A healthy diet includes getting lean protein from sources like skinless chicken or turkey, tofu, and nuts. Most people need around 50-60 g of protein every day. [2] X Research source A 3 ounces (85 g) serving of chicken or turkey has 19 g of protein. A serving of yogurt has around 17 g of protein. 1 egg has about 6 g of protein. [3] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source

steps.title: Incorporate healthy fats into your diet.
steps.content: Incorporate healthy fats into your diet. Healthy fats can make your meals tastier and keep you fuller for longer, meaning you will snack less. The healthiest fats are monounsaturated fats, but polyunsaturated fats aren't bad for you. Avoid trans fats and saturated fats entirely, if possible. [4] X Trustworthy Source HelpGuide Nonprofit organization dedicated to providing free, evidence-based mental health and wellness resources. Go to source Good sources of healthy fats include avocados, nuts, olive oil, tuna, and salmon.

steps.title: Lower the amount of simple and processed carbs you eat.
steps.content: Lower the amount of simple and processed carbs you eat. Some people who take prednisone have success managing their weight by drastically reducing the amount of carbs they eat, or even cutting carbs entirely out of their diets. Try to minimize the amount of processed carbs you eat to manage your weight. [5] X Research source Sources of simple and processed carbs to avoid include bread, pastries, sodas, potatoes, and pasta.

steps.title: Eat a diet that is low in sodium.
steps.content: Eat a diet that is low in sodium . Sodium causes fluid retention, which is one cause of weight gain that is common on prednisone. Keep your daily sodium intake below 2000 milligrams a day, if you can. [6] X Research source You can reduce your sodium intake by not adding salt to your food and avoiding prepackaged or processed foods.

steps.title: Add some potassium into your diet.
steps.content: Add some potassium into your diet. Eating more potassium can help limit the amount of water your body retains. It also reduces the amount of sodium in your body. It also flushes out extra fluids. [7] X Research source Some high potassium foods include dried plums, spinach, bananas, raisins, squash, yogurt, and milk.

steps.title: Keep hydrated
steps.content: Keep hydrated by drinking plenty of water. Drinking more water can keep you fuller for longer, so if you have an increased appetite, try drinking a glass of water before you snack. Drinking water instead of soda or other sweetened beverages can also cut extra sugar and carbs out of your diet. [8] X Research source If you are thirsty, you are probably dehydrated. Drink enough water throughout the day so that you never feel thirsty.

steps.title: Exercise
steps.content: Exercise for at least 15 minutes, 5 times a week. It can be difficult to add exercise into your life when you are taking prednisone. Start with something you know you can accomplish, like a brisk, 15-minute walk. Ramp up the level of your exercise, if you can. [9] X Research source Some exercise is better than no exercise. You don't need to do intense exercise every day to see benefits from moving your body.

steps.title: Tell your doctor about any increased appetite, bloating, or constipation.
steps.content: Tell your doctor about any increased appetite, bloating, or constipation. Prednisone can cause lots of unpleasant side effects that can contribute to weight gain. Prednisone can change your appetite and make you more prone to snacking or overeating, but it can also cause bloating and constipation. Talking to your doctor about these side effects can help you come up with an action plan. [10] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source You might be able to manage these side effects by changing your dosage.

steps.title: Ask your doctor about medications that can balance out side effects.
steps.content: Ask your doctor about medications that can balance out side effects. Depending on the symptoms you experience, your doctor might be able to prescribe other medications that can counteract your side effects. Talk to your doctor first before adding any additional medications to your routine. [11] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source For example, if you have an increased appetite, you may be able to take a mild appetite suppressant.

steps.title: Ask your doctor to reduce your dosage as much as possible.
steps.content: Ask your doctor to reduce your dosage as much as possible. The higher you dosage is, the more likely you are to experience side effects. If it's possible with your condition, ask your doctor if you can reduce your dosage. [12] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Always talk to your doctor before making any changes to your medication.

steps.title: Take prednisone for as short of a period as you can.
steps.content: Take prednisone for as short of a period as you can. No matter how low your dose is, taking prednisone for a long period of time will most likely cause some weight gain. Work with your doctor to try to work out a timeline for your treatment that is as short as possible. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Ask your doctor how prednisone interacts with other medicines you take.
steps.content: Ask your doctor how prednisone interacts with other medicines you take. Prednisone can interact with other medications, like aspirin, butabarbital, and fluconazole, and make side effects worse. Ask your doctor if it would be better to find another medication or temporarily stop taking a medication if it interacts with prednisone. [14] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source In some cases, you may need to continue taking your medication with prednisone, even if it causes side effects.
